headline: Best Cake Doughnuts
description: This cake donut recipe is simple to make, lightly spiced with cinnamon and nutmeg, and delicious coated with cinnamon sugar or a powdered sugar glaze.
name: Best Cake Doughnuts

recipeInstructions.text: Heat oil in a deep-fryer to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
Sift together flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, cinnamon, and nutmeg in a large bowl. Mix in butter until crumbly. Stir in milk and egg until smooth.
Knead lightly, then turn out onto a lightly floured surface. Roll or pat to 1/4-inch thickness. Cut with a doughnut cutter, or use two round biscuit cutters of different sizes.
Lay doughnuts in hot oil, a few at a time. Do not overcrowd the pan, or oil may overflow. Fry, turning once, until golden, about 3 minutes. Drain on paper towels.

review.reviewBody: First doughnuts I have made. simple ingredients, simple cooking. I used a deep fat fryer but less cooking time. Will definitely make the again.
So easy to make and to let the kids help. Taste great
Easy and delicious! A big hit with my family!
Made as described, very straight forward. The only problem I had was not having a thermometer to control the oil temperature. Other than that, awesome!
Deep fried them in tallow for Chanukah, they were delicious. Threw them in some powdered sugar for topping. They were very easy to make and took no time at all. This is a keeper!!

I love it so much so tasty it's true it is the best doughnut ever that came out so perfect I love it so, of course, I got to add my touch to it so I drizzle a little maple syrup, and boy it was the best for sure doing this again I will make this for my kids every Friday and they can't wait to Friday comes there teens so you already know they stay in ben late but when Friday comes they will be up before I am
i LOVED this, and im not a dessert guy!

Easy, tasty. I put sliced apples in the middle of two thin sheets and it turned out great. this needs very little mixing. I used a plug in fryer and checked the oil temp. 3 min for a 1/4 inch piece of dough was plenty. Not sure what the people who had problems did, but my guess is they had old oil, old baking powder, gluten free flour, and no thermometer. Maybe they are just the kind of people who claim " I did exactly what the directions said" when in fact they have no idea how to follow directions beyond " click here" Oh, I used more nutmeg because I like nutmeg.
Decreased fry time from 3 minutes to 1:15. Perfect quick donut recipe!!
Easy and tasty
Excellent texture! My only suggestion is to use a deep pan/pot for frying otherwise they get too crispy.
Tastes better with sprinkles and frosting!
Horrible recipe. I make donuts a lot, and tried this one, unfortunately. The measurements are way off. Sticky and gross. Thanks for nothing.
I made the recipe as is and they turned out great!!
Grand flavour but too wet to roll out so small spoons deep-fried into mini doughnuts
I followed the directions exactly and they were very good.

Made this yesterday. Easy recipe. Donuts were nice and crispy on the outside and cake like on the inside. Tasted great warm and tasted just as good the next day. I dredged them in some cinnamon sugar shortly after coming out of the fryer. Will make these again.
This recipe was pretty good in taste, but odd in form. I tried to shape them like doughnuts, but they came out like blobs. But, that might just be me.

Cake doughnuts are my favorite food and these are perfect: not too pretty with a craggy look and dense. I eat 'em plain with no sugar coating . My doughnut cutter is a bit larger than normal and I got ten doughnuts from this recipe. I also put a quarter teaspoon of nutmeg in rather than just a dash. These are awesome!

Just made them and my family is gobbling them down. I fear they won't see breakfast lol..the recipe is very easy to follow. I'm impressed at how soft they are inside. I didnt coat them with any sweetness the 1/2 cup sugar is fine for us.
Great cake donuts!
Loved it. As my son said 10 out of 10. Simple and quick. Just like my grandma's cake donuts. I did add extra flour but putting in the fridge ahead will help the dough be less sticky too.
I made it twice and both times my dough is runny.

Excellent!!! My husband loves cake doughnuts with maple glaze and he’s decided these are as good as he gets in town! Just two of us so rolled out and cut out, then fry half and put the rest of the unfried ones in the fridge til the next day. Used the recommendation to use a tad bit more flour... perfect!!

These donuts are delicious! I did glaze them instead of coating them in sugar and cinnamon, but I ate a couple of holes before the glaze, and they were very good. Also, I made them dairy free with almond milk and Becel sticks.
wow I dont know whats up with this recipe. It ended up as a cake batter not a dough.
Turned out perfect. I got about 8 donuts total but I made them pretty big. Flavor was spot on!
Delicious! Quick and easy and the family loved them. I put chocolate frosting on them, but they are great plain, too. I also rolled the holes in cinnamon sugar. Yum!
I put a little pumpkin spice in it as well turned out great

The only changes I made were to double the nutmeg and cinnamon . They were perfect. It's always tricky for me to get my oil just right and keep it at the perfect temp, so I had a couple that were a little browner than the others. My fault, not the doughnuts! LOL. I Dipped them in cinnamon/sugar when I took them out of the oil. I may try to glaze them next time. Thanks for the recipe!
Very good! Refrigerated the unused dough and made the rest the next day - might even have been better the second time!

This is a really good recipe. I was pleasantly surprised. The dough texture was nice, but needed a gentle touch for sure. I made donuts and holes. If one is a novice and anxious about handling the dough too much, by all means just make holes. They are crispy on the outside but quite tender on the inside. This recipe is a real treat.
Really good, made them all lockdown.

There are both good and bad aspects to this recipe. There are complaints of the dough being sticky. This is appropriate because the dough must be kneaded, which requires a floured surface. The process of kneading on the floured surface will give you the desired texture. I imagine adding too much flour would create a thick inedible mess or a biscuit The donuts expanded to 3-4 times the rolled thickness. Use this as your guide for how thick you roll them out. They fried beautifully and the texture was great. I deep fried so that may have helped. As for the bad. That donut itself was quite bland. I would experiment the next time, but this was the first time making them so I followed the directions. I tossed some in cinnamon and sugar and others in powdered sugar. My family loved them....so I'd make them again and maybe add more cinnamon and nutmeg..or vanilla
Delicious! We added a little extra nutmeg and cinnamon and did not dip them...pure goodness!

These were SO GOOD!!!!! I made these with my 3 year old. The recipe was simple enough for us to make together (though I did the frying part solo for safety). We just used a really deep pot for the oil along with chopsticks for flipping the doughnuts and a smaller metal strainer to get them out and it worked great. Took a few tries to get the temp and doughnut thickness right and then we were in business. Outstanding. My husband and I can't stop eating them, which isn't great since we're still sheltering-in-place and can't go to the gym haha! Added some frosting and sprinkles for fun and enjoyed.

I didn’t have regular milk so I used heavy cream. They tasted great! I don’t have a deep frier so I used 1 1/2” of oil in a sauce pan and cooked one at a time. Half turned out amazing and half disintegrated. I’m guessing my oil temp changed. But all and all a success! My kids loved them and it made it feel like donut Sunday at church. The chocolate topped and granulated sugar and cinnamon dipped worked great. I think the powdered sugar needed to dry out more.

Phenomenal. Only my second time attempting donuts and these turned out far better than my first attempt! The only change I made was adding about a teaspoon of nutmeg and cinnamon. I made them for several friends, family and neighbors and everyone loved them. I fried them in canola oil in a cast iron dutch oven. I let it heat up for 15 minutes at medium heat and perfect frying every batch. I don’t own a thermometer so I had trouble with the oil getting too hot in the past with other pans but this was great! Great recipe for better-than-bakery donuts!
Fastest donuts recipe I've ever made! Turned out crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Perfect "not too sweet" donuts.
My Grandsons liked them

I had not made fresh homemade donuts before. I had always used the canned biscuits. These were much better! I did not shape the donuts but just made donut holes. I did let the batter sit for about 30 minutes before placing them in the oil. My granddaughters and I had a great time rolling them in sugar before popping them in our mouths. This may become a grandma tradition when my granddaughters come for sleepovers .

I know these aren't raised doughnuts, but they weren't like cake doughnuts either. Very hard, I tried to cook them for the full 3 minutes, but they got so dark. I used a thermometer to make sure oil was the right temp. This was my second try and the oil seems to turn brown. Is there a special oil to use. First used vegetable oil, second canola.

I worked the first time I made it, but this weekend I tried again and the batter wasn't thick enough. I tried again and it still didn't work. As much as I followed the directions to the T, it didn't work. I don't want to rate it any higher or lower than three stars because, when the worked, they were amazing. When it didn't though, I didnt have any idea of what had happened. All in all, great when they actually worked out.
Super easy and great tasting. Substituted milk for buttermilk and made a lemon glaze to coat then in....Delicious!
I made it but refrigerated it over night and added more cinnamon and nutmeg. Made doughnut holes mostly, love those, just pop them into your mouth on the run! They were a big hit!
I added a bit to much oil, but when they finished I tasted them and they were delicious. A bit chewy but good.

I normally make the yeast risen type doughnuts, but not having the time or extra flour, I decided to try this recipe. Let me just say I am glad I ventured to try this one. I love it! I should have known when the first step in the recipe states to heat the oil, that it would go much faster than my normal 60-90 minute wait time..This is the best recipe for ingredients,time and taste. and speaking of taste..I was a bit skeptical of how they would taste, but I had nothing to worry about, these are great! Thank you Jennifer for sharing this great recipe! I made doughnuts, donut holes and benets and they barely were cooled enough to eat when the last one was going, going, GONE! :)
First time ever attempting donuts. Very easy, very tasty...we did double the cinnamon to a 1/2 tsp. They were great without frosting or extra sugar!

Very good base recipe. I’ve made these as written and I’ve modified them. I can’t have dairy anymore, so I just made them with margarine and oat milk and the texture was still perfect. I also add more cinnamon and a LOT more nutmeg (1/2 teaspoon of each) and roll them in granulated sugar after they come out of the fryer. Yum!
This worked very nicely. Dough easy to roll, lovely crisp outside when done. Could maybe use just a little more sweetness. I might add an extra bit of sugar the next time I make it.
Perfection. I made them exactly as written.. so easy.

Worked great and easy to make by hand without a mixer like some other recipes seem to require. I don’t have a deep fryer so I did them one at a time in a small pot to conserve oil and did my best to regulate temperature. Would add a little less sugar next time as I prefer them very “plain.” Made my family very happy this morning!

This is my first time making Dough and Doughnuts. It was really Easy and they were good. Yes they aren’t the fluffy Yest kind but amazing all the same. I realized after I started making it I didn’t have Nutmeg and so I added another Teaspoon of Cinnamon. Because it was my first time I decided made all the doughnuts dark in color to be sure they cooked all the way. My brothers cut the Doughnut shape from Mason Jar Lids and the Doughnut holes we made from Baby-food container.
Added about a 1/8 to 1/4 cup of additional flour because the dough was to sticky

These turned out fantastic! I just LOVE making these doughnuts! A tip: don't use lactose free milk. I tried to make these the second time around without the lactose so my sister could enjoy them; but, they turned out tasting horrible!
I love this simple recipe. It's fun to make with my children each winter school holidays. It's become a family tradition in our house!
i followed this recipe exactly and it turned out fantastic and just what i was looking for...will definitely use it again...so easy and delicious
WOW... so quick and easy!!!!!!!!!..... i am amazed!!.... my kids will be so happy as now i can make donuts more often... Ty Jennifer Long :)
these are good and easy
these were delicious but they hardened within 2 hours. definitely going to remake these
Delicious! The only thing I did different was left out nutmeg....didn’t have any. Put in a little extra cinnamon. Will definitely be making again soon!
Awesome, easy, and fast. I added little more cinnamon. Came out great thank you
Outstanding! Delicious and will make them again soon.

This was my first time making doughnuts and I was somewhat apprehensive going in. I was not disappointed! I followed the instructions to the letter and had no problems. I used a deep fryer and only cooked two at a time. I did put some store-bought frosting on them after they were done, but with the cinnamon and nutmeg they taste good without any extras.
Definitely best with just a simple cinnamon sugar coating. Don’t need full 3 minutes on oil. 2 or less.
They came out tasty!

My husband loved these!! We do not roll in sugar, glaze etc. as we like them plain.I follow the recipe exactly. I have made these several times and my only problem is getting the oil temperature just right. I use a cast iron skillet and check the temp.of my oil before each batch I'm frying. If making more than one recipe I have found I need to change my oil after one recipe as it is too dirty. I probably should invest in a deep fryer to solve my problem. Eventually I will get this down to an art. LOL, Thank you for sharing this recipe .
Great quick treat. Didn't change a thing. 3 mins of frying made the outside crisp and the middle chewy

**2nd time making. Perfect. I used 3/4 c. sugar, 1 t. vanilla and 1/2 t. cinnamon. Needed no sugar dusted on top. ***

Orig: The recipe I've been looking for - yay. We used to get plain donuts from this local market years ago and it's been long gone and we still think of the donuts... these are as close as I'm going to get according to husband. Did add a little more cinnamon and nutmeg, and also about .5-1 t. vanilla. I might add more sugar to the mix, as I like them plain, and I did have to dust a tad powdered sugar on them so will try with more sugar in the mix next time. Thanks for this recipe!
These are simple and delicious. I used them to make donut holes. Big hit at work!

Made these for the first time Christmas morning, there wasn’t a crumb left! Everyone loved them. I had to make them again for my 8 year old son the next morning! Just made them a 3rd time for my nephews who slept over last night. They requested glazed, cinnamon sugar and plain, and I’m happy to oblige. These are super easy and delicious. Enjoy!

This was my first time making donuts and these were delicious. I don't have any cutters so I just dropped small spoonful of dough into deep fryer and it worked perfect. Thanks for the easy recipe. My husband also loves these yummy little bites.

I've made raised donuts for years but never cake donuts. However, that will change because these were delicious and easy. Plus they don't require raising. I made them for an annual neighborhood donut party where there were hundreds of raised donuts, and mine were the only cake donuts. The cake donuts were a bit hit! I like that they have some spice and some sweetness; I also like the cake texture.

A few notes. As others suggested, I increased the cinnamon and nutmeg, and I also added some vanilla. And I rolled them out a bit thicker than just 1/4 inch. Other than that, I followed the recipe as is and had no problems. I will say that I was surprised to not get more donuts from the recipe. I made a double batch and ended up with only about 3 dozen donuts plus holes. Next time I will know what the yield is.

We served a variety of glazes with all of the donuts--vanilla, orange, chocolate, maple, and mixed berry. All worked well with these donuts.
Nice simple cake donuts recipe, very filling. My family enjoyed it and I will make again. People need process what they read. It is an old fashion cake donuts recipe, not a yeast one. I knew it.
These are fantastic either on its own or with a cup a coffee!

They were ok but nothing like I expected. I watched the temp closely and they still browned a lot quicker than 3 minutes as the recipe stated. Flip after 30 seconds and they’re done in about a minute.

I followed the recipe as instructed. Only change I made was the flour which I added 1/4 cup more. I beat the egg, added the melted butter and used milk with 2 tsp. of lemon juice. The dough came out slightly sticky, but floured the parchment paper and just pressed out the dough. Using doughnut cutter, I got fifteen doughnut and 15 doughnut holes. Made icing using 2 tablespoon of melted butter, 1 cup powdered sugar, and milk as needed. I added 1/2 tsp. of citrus flavoring. Dipped the fried doughnuts and got the glaze needed to put them over the top! Awesome!! Family loved them! By the way, they were not heavy or dense. They are just right on.

I increased the cinnamon a bit and rolled them in cinnamon sugar. Good! I think my oil was a bit too hot for 3 minutes so the first ones came out a little hard. Probably will go a minute and a half each side next time.

Really easy. They puff right up from the 1/4 inch you rolled. Very good. I put in extra nutmeg but couldnt really taste it. I was wishing my fryer went higher that 375 thinking they may not come out so greasy if they cooked faster.
As another reviewer suggested, I added flour to help these roll out, and used more cinnamon and nutmeg. They were absolutely delicious.
love it and it tournd out good
I hate doughnuts but these are AMAZING they tase just like a funnel cake
Easy to make and delicious. I made mine cinnamon sugar. It disappeared. Everyone loves them.

Thanks for this simple recipe. I never made my own donuts before, but was looking for a good, easy dessert for which I could use ingredients already in my poorly stocked kitchen. Other than needing to substitute half&half for the milk, I had all I needed to make these (well, no deep fryer, either, but a large, deep skillet and lots of oil...). I am still letting most of them cool down, but what I've tasted so far is so good! I was like a little kid when they plumped up, I was so proud that I actually made them right! I'm glad they aren't too sweet, not too anything, just right for cake donuts.

I have made these twice now and both times they were excellent. But the second time around I did add more cinnamon and nutmeg which really enhanced the flavor. Either way they were quick and easy and delicious!

I followed another reviewer's advice to use a cookie scoop and make "drop doughnut holes" rather than true doughnuts. They were predictably not so pretty, with a heavy crust that absorbed a lot of oil. Still yummy, though! Since that method saved me the trouble and mess of rolling them out and adding floor, I was very happy with the change. It was fairly easy and quick, for a weekday breakfast treat! 

I heated the oil on medium, with a thermometer in at all times to keep an eye on it. I would set each batch (4-5 "holes" at a time in my medium-sized pot) on paper towels briefly to drain, then tossed half the "holes" with cinnamon sugar in a brown paper bag, and sifted powdered sugar over the other half. Everyone enjoyed them! Thanks for the recipe. :-)

I am new to baking I think its cool to take these separate ingredients and turn them into something good. I tried these donuts and found they were easy to make and they came out very good. I covered them with powdered sugar. I am not sure if I should have let them cool before I covered them or cover them while they are hot. I tried both and they both had problems. but both tasted good.
I added more nutmeg definitely more than a dash and it's just the taste I was looking for.

These were amazing! It was my first time making doughnuts, and it went extremely well. We dipped them in cinnamon and sugar instead of putting the cinnamon in the doughnuts, and they were heavenly. Would definitely make again! The only annoying part was that the dough was SO sticky, and was extremely hard to get off my hands. Would definitely use a lot more flour.
Perfect! This recipe turned out great. I highly recommend it.
I just made them for my husbands Bible study .instead of making the rounds donuts I just made the holes. Everyone loved them they were a big hit going to do it again
Did that recipe last week and the only thing I changed was the shape. I did bolls and they taste a fabulous
Love it
I have made this twice now! First time I used too much flour and I over worked the batter. The donuts were still yummy but didn't rise very much due to the over working of the dough.
Fantastic
I also needed to add extra flour to roll out doughnuts but otherwise they were a big hit with the family.
Ihave not made them yet
NO. Flavour was fine but I did not like the texture after baking.
Yum!
